visibility_factors: Periods of near-zero visibility reported in the hourly forecast (possible fog/low stratus or reporting artifact)

alert_summary.description: Cold Weather Advisory in effect from 1 AM Friday to 10 AM Saturday (wind chills 20 to 25 below zero expected Friday morning).
Extreme Cold Watch mentions wind chills as low as 25 below possible late Thursday night through Saturday morning (monitor for upgrade).
Winter Weather Advisory primarily impacts Thursday through 7 PM Thursday; could leave residual slick spots going into Friday.

meteorology.overall_conditions_summary: For Rockford, MI on Friday (2026-01-23), the primary hazard is extreme cold and wind chills rather than falling snow: forecast shows 0" snowfall/0" liquid, with temperatures staying well below freezing all day (low near -14°F, morning temps near 5°F and wind chills around -15°F to -25°F). Winds are breezy early (NW/WNW ~13–17 mph, gusts ~20–26 mph overnight), reinforcing dangerous wind chills and potential frostbite risk. Visibility is generally listed ~6 miles, but several overnight/late-day hours report 0–1 mile/near-zero visibility and a mention of freezing fog late evening, which could create localized slick spots and poor visibility—especially on untreated roads/bridges after Thursday’s snow/ice. Snow-day potential from snow accumulation alone is low for Friday, but a delayed start/cancellation becomes more plausible if the district uses wind-chill thresholds or if freezing fog/leftover ice produces hazardous morning travel.

similar_weather_patterns.pattern_description: Arctic high pressure settling in behind a departing lake-effect / synoptic snow event: fresh snowpack from the prior 24–48 hours, then a rapid temperature crash with clearing/overcast and diminishing precip. Operationally this often shifts the decision driver from ‘snow amount’ to ‘extreme cold + reduced morning mobility.’

Extreme cold morning with modest wind (10–20 mph) producing wind chills near or below -20°F around bus pickup time, but with little/no new snow falling. In West Michigan this most often leads to delayed starts or selective rural-route cancellations rather than full-district closures unless wind chills meet/beat local thresholds for multiple hours.

Freezing fog / near-zero visibility occurring late night into early morning after a cold, moist airmass (often following snow). This is a ‘surprise’ hazard pattern: black ice on untreated roads + sudden visibility drops. When it coincides with commute/bus window, closures become more likely than the snow totals suggest.

seasonal_context.typical_conditions_for_date: Late January in Rockford (Kent County) is climatologically one of the coldest parts of the year, but school closures are still more commonly triggered by (1) heavy snow with bad timing (often 8–10+ inches overnight or during the AM commute), (2) ice storms/freezing rain, or (3) truly dangerous wind chills (often around -15°F to -25°F) especially when paired with transportation risk. A ‘dry but brutally cold’ day is less likely to close schools than an icy or high-impact snow day.
unusual_factors: Forecast temperatures are very low for a school day: high near 5°F and low near -14°F.
Wind chills around the morning commute window are modeled near -20°F to about -27°F (most critical roughly 6–10 AM).
Visibility signals are concerning in spots (several hours show near-zero visibility; late-night freezing fog is explicitly indicated).
Preceding day includes light freezing rain / snow and an advisory, which increases the odds of residual slick spots/black ice even if Friday is dry.

local_microclimates: West Michigan ‘snowbelt’ variability: lingering lake-effect bands can leave very different road conditions over short distances (Rockford vs. nearby higher/lower terrain and corridors).
Rural/edge-of-district roads and bridges tend to ice faster in arctic air, especially after prior-day mixed precip.
River valleys/low spots can trap fog, and with subzero wind chills, any moisture on pavement can refreeze quickly.
infrastructure_considerations: Michigan districts typically keep operating through moderate snow totals; decision pressure increases more from ice + low visibility + extreme wind chills during bus stop times.
If the district has many bus riders waiting outdoors, a sustained -20°F to -25°F wind chill window around 6–9 AM is a key operational trigger.
Even with no new snow, staffing and student safety concerns rise when frostbite risk becomes meaningful within typical wait times.
location_specific_factors.elevation_impact: Rockford’s modest elevation/rolling terrain won’t ‘create’ heavy snow by itself, but it can amplify localized icing and drifting issues on open stretches when winds are 15–20 mph, especially if there is leftover powder from the prior day.

history.confidence_assessment: For Friday 2026-01-23, the snow-day risk is being driven primarily by extreme cold (morning wind chills near -20°F to about -27°F) and potential visibility/ice issues (near-zero vis signals and late-night freezing fog), not by snowfall (0" forecast). In Michigan—especially in West Michigan—schools rarely close just for cold unless wind chills meet district thresholds for multiple hours during the AM bus window, or cold coincides with widespread icy/low-visibility travel. Given: (1) no new snow, (2) winds not blizzard-level, but (3) very dangerous wind chills and some fog/visibility flags plus prior-day mixed precip, the overall closure probability looks low-to-moderate, with a meaningful chance of a delayed start or selective cancellations if wind chills verify near -25°F and/or freezing fog/black ice impacts the morning commute. Confidence is medium because the ‘school decision’ hinges on small timing differences (fog and the coldest wind chill window).

safety_recommendations: Primary operational issue is *extreme cold*, not snow: morning wind chills near ~-20°F to -25°F (Cold Weather Advisory) increase frostbite risk for students waiting at bus stops and for any outdoor supervision.

Roads: no new snow/ice is forecast on Friday (0 precip), so main roads should be in decent shape after overnight plowing/salting from Thursday’s wintry weather. Expect some lingering slick spots on untreated residential/side roads and in shaded areas.

Black ice potential: even without precipitation, temperatures staying well below freezing (single digits, subzero wind chills) can preserve refreeze on bridges/overpasses and any areas that stayed wet/slushy Thursday. Treat as a *spot-ice* morning.

Visibility: forecast shows periods of very low visibility overnight/early morning in the model data (some hours reporting 0–1 mi/near-zero). Even if that’s overdone, patchy haze/fog can combine with darkness (sunrise ~8:06 AM) to reduce contrast and make slick spots harder to see.
Bus operations: consider cold-weather protocols—reduce student wait times, ensure buses can start reliably, verify diesel treatment/fuel, and have contingency for mechanical no-starts.

If you are deciding on closure/delay: a *2-hour delay* can materially reduce exposure at bus stops by shifting peak pickup closer to/after sunrise and slightly warmer temps; closure is less likely based on road conditions alone given no additional snow forecast.
Messaging to families: emphasize layered clothing, covered skin (hat/gloves/face covering), and minimizing time outside; remind drivers to slow down on bridges and neighborhood roads.

local_news.summary: A winter weather advisory covering multiple counties (including Kent) warned of several inches of snow, slippery travel, and noted lake-effect snow could persist through Friday, with dangerously cold air (subzero lows/wind chills) building in late week.

This indicates districts in the Rockford area have already been willing to close this week under the current cold/snow pattern.

They also published a specific post for Thu/Fri outlooks (some content requires subscription), indicating the region is actively tracking closure potential into Fri 01/23.

official_announcements: Forest Hills School District posted a recent operational weather response earlier this week: a 2-hour delay on Tuesday, January 20, 2026 due to cold temperatures (shows sensitivity to cold).

Rockford-area districts publicly reiterate that closure/delay decisions are typically made very early morning based on road conditions + weather + wind chill; Rockford Public Schools communications emphasize wind chill thresholds can trigger discussion (e.g., very low wind chills).

reported_road_conditions: Regional signal: hazardous travel/road conditions have been significant enough to produce widespread West Michigan school closures midweek (per FOX 17) and a winter weather advisory including Kent County (per Big Rapids News advisory roundup).
No direct Rockford-specific road commission live-condition statement was successfully captured in this pass (many road condition maps are interactive and don’t render in text scrape).
local_event_cancellations: Non-school cancellation signal: a Friday, Jan. 23 weather-related cancellation was observed outside West Michigan (Northeast Indiana Solid Waste Management District), indicating broader regional disruption potential, but it is not a Kent County-specific indicator.

news.key_findings_summary: For Friday, January 23, 2026 in the Rockford (Kent County) area, the strongest "closure pressure" signals I could confirm online are: (1) Kent County being included in a winter weather advisory coverage area with snow continuing into Friday and extreme cold building (including subzero/wind-chill concerns), and (2) a clear precedent of widespread closures earlier this same week across nearby districts (Rockford and Forest Hills included) due to freezing weather and snowy roads. I did NOT find a specific, official Rockford Public Schools announcement yet for Fri 01/23 in the sources captured here, and I could not reliably extract Rockford-specific road-condition map text or a definitive Consumers Energy outage spike from the interactive tools in this scrape. Net: conditions and recent district behavior support elevated closure/delay risk, but the definitive signal (official district post or a cluster of neighboring districts announcing for Fri) was not yet visible in what I captured.

primary_factors: No new snow/precip expected Friday morning (snow-driven closure risk is low)
Extreme cold is the main hazard: temps near 4–6°F at 6–9 AM with wind chills roughly -12 to -15°F (headline advisory mentions pockets nearer -20 to -25°F)
High refreeze/black-ice risk on secondary roads/bridges from Thursday’s mixed precip + temps plunging; salt effectiveness reduced at very low temps
No credible, consistent signal of freezing fog/near-zero visibility during the 6–9 AM commute (stronger fog signal appears late evening); low-vis values look partly artifact
No confirmed Friday closure/delay announcements from neighboring districts yet; no confirmed outage spike

timeline.conditions_start: 2026-01-23 05:00 (coldest/most hazardous bus-stop and refreeze window begins)
timeline.peak_impact_time: 2026-01-23 06:00–08:30 (bus pickups + darkness + spot black ice + harsh wind chills)
timeline.conditions_improve: 2026-01-23 09:30–11:00 (daylight and slight warming; main roads likely improved, residual icy spots linger)

final.decision_rationale:
Pre-decision checklist synthesis:
1) Agreement: All experts agree Friday is a cold-driven day with near-zero new snow, with the meaningful risks being wind-chill exposure and leftover/refreeze slick spots (especially secondary roads). Also agreement that a delay is more plausible than a full closure.
2) Disagreement: (a) How much to weight the near-zero visibility/freezing-fog signal—meteorology indicates it is not consistent in the 6–9 AM window and may be artifact; (b) how bad secondary-road icing could be—safety upgraded black-ice likelihood to high given refreeze + reduced salt effectiveness.
3) Plow timing math: Conservative precip-impact end ~20:00 Thu → ~11h40m of treatment time to 07:40 Fri. That is typically enough for priority routes, but not a guarantee for neighborhoods/bridges in extreme cold.
4) Ice: No new freezing rain expected Friday, but refreeze/black ice risk is meaningful (this is the main travel hazard).
5) Neighboring districts: No confirmed Friday closures/delays posted yet in captured checks (so no +15–20% bump).
6) What would make me wrong: If wind chills verify closer to -20 to -25°F for multiple hours at pickup time (district threshold trigger), or if black ice is widespread on secondary roads, or if fog/visibility collapses near dawn despite the point forecast.

Weighting (per system): Meteorology 30% (dry, cold; commute wind chills around -12 to -15°F; fog not strongly supported at 6–9 AM), Safety 20% (high refreeze/black ice on secondary roads; main roads likely OK), History 15% (dry-but-brutal cold usually yields delays/partial impacts more than full closures), News 15% (no Friday closure announcements found yet; earlier-week closures provide only a modest nudge). Remaining 20% (infrastructure/power grid folded into safety/news): no confirmed outage spike.

Michigan threshold application: This is not a snowfall-total day (0" forecast), so baseline would be low (≈5–15%). I raise it into the mid-20s because (1) refreeze/black ice risk after prior mixed precip in arctic air, and (2) cold-exposure operational pressure for bus riders. I do NOT push higher because (a) wind chills in the specific 6–9 AM point forecast are closer to -12 to -15°F (below the -15 to -20°F “many close” band), (b) no verified fog during commute, and (c) no neighboring-district Friday closure confirmations yet.

Net: 26% for a full snow day/closure (with a higher likelihood of a 2-hour delay than a full closure).

alternative_scenarios.scenario: Wind chills verify at/colder than -20°F for multiple hours during 6–9 AM + widespread bus-stop exposure concerns (policy-driven call)
alternative_scenarios.impact: 2-hour delay becomes likely; full closure becomes plausible if sustained and paired with any road issues

alternative_scenarios.scenario: Secondary-road black ice is widespread (multiple AM crashes/road commission advisories) despite dry forecast
alternative_scenarios.impact: Closure probability jumps; at minimum, significant delays or selective route cancellations

alternative_scenarios.scenario: Conditions verify better than feared (no fog, minimal refreeze, winds lighter)
alternative_scenarios.impact: Normal school day; possibly cold-weather precautions only

for_schools: Plan operationally for a 2-hour delay as the most likely disruption option (reduces bus-stop exposure and adds daylight for spotting ice).
Run an early AM spot-check on secondary roads/bridges/hills (especially rural edges) rather than relying on main-road conditions.
Implement cold protocols: minimize outdoor wait time, allow indoor waiting where possible, confirm buses can start (diesel treatment) and have spare capacity for no-starts.
for_residents: Assume black ice on neighborhood streets/bridges; slow down and increase following distance.
Dress for exposed skin protection at bus stops; limit time outside.
Check district communications early (typically 5–6:30 AM) and allow extra commute time.
for_authorities: Prioritize bridge decks, shaded curves, and school-zone approaches for treatment; monitor for refreeze where salt is less effective.
If crash/slide-offs cluster pre-dawn, issue targeted advisories quickly (this is the main factor that could swing a closure).
Coordinate with districts on real-time secondary-road status rather than only MDOT trunklines.

positions.rationale: Meteorologically, Friday (2026-01-23) looks like a **high-impact cold day** rather than a snowstorm day: highs near **5°F**, lows near **-14°F**, and a dangerous **wind-chill window around the bus-stop hours**. However, because the forecast has **no new precipitation/snowfall**, roads should generally improve vs. Thursday, which usually keeps full-district closures less common. I land in a **low-to-moderate** snow-day probability bucket, with the main upside risk coming from (a) district wind-chill thresholds and (b) any unexpectedly widespread freezing fog/near-zero visibility or refreeze problems during the morning commute.
keyFactors: **No new snow expected Friday (0" / 0 mm)**: the forecast is essentially dry all day, so the classic “can’t clear roads” trigger is absent.

**Extreme cold is the main hazard**: temps around 3–6°F during the morning commute with **wind chills roughly -20°F to -27°F** (Cold Weather Advisory window 1 AM Fri–10 AM Sat). That can trigger a delay/closure in some districts, but it’s policy-dependent.

**Wind not extreme/blizzard-level**: sustained ~13–17 mph early with gusts ~20–26 mph is enough to drive wind chills down, but not enough by itself to create widespread drifting/whiteouts without falling snow.

**Residual impacts from Thursday**: Winter Weather Advisory prior day (snow + some mixed precip) raises odds of **leftover slick spots/black ice**, especially on untreated roads/bridges in arctic air.

**Visibility signals are messy/uncertain**: several hourly entries show 0–1 mi / “0” visibility and there’s **freezing fog late (23:00)**. If that were to occur **during 6–9 AM**, closure odds would jump; as shown, it’s more late-night/overnight and may be a reporting artifact.

positions.rationale: From a historical/operations lens in West Michigan, full closures are most common with high-impact snow/ice timing. Friday 2026-01-23 looks “dry but dangerously cold,” which more often produces a 2-hour delay or targeted rural-route cancellations rather than a full district shutdown. That said, the forecast places wind chills near/below ~-25°F right in the morning decision window, and the prior-day wintry weather increases the chance that lingering slick spots combine with darkness (sunrise ~8:06 AM) to create enough transportation risk to justify broader action. Netting those factors, I land in the high-20s for a full snow day, with a higher implied probability of some disruption (delay/partial cancellations) than of a full closure.
keyFactors: No new precip forecast Friday (0" snow / 0" precip), so the classic high-probability “overnight heavy snow” closure trigger is absent.
Cold is the main driver: forecast wind chills roughly -20°F to about -27°F during typical bus-stop window (about 6–9 AM) and an active Cold Weather Advisory covering that period.

Thursday’s wintry mix/snow + advisory increases the odds of residual slick spots/black ice on untreated roads/bridges even if Friday is dry, which historically is what turns a “cold-only” day into an operational problem.

Visibility flags (several hours with near-zero visibility values + freezing fog later) raise a low-confidence but non-trivial risk of localized travel hazards; if this verifies near the morning commute, it meaningfully bumps closure odds.

Regional/district behavior signal: nearby districts (and Rockford-area districts) have already closed/delayed earlier this week under this same cold/snow regime—this makes a cold-driven delay/closure more plausible than in a “normal” winter week.

positions.rationale: From a safety standpoint, Friday 2026-01-23 in Rockford, MI looks like a *cold-driven decision day*, not a snow-accumulation day. With 0 precip forecast, I expect road conditions to be mostly manageable on main routes, keeping the baseline closure probability relatively low. However, the Cold Weather Advisory (wind chills ~-20°F to -25°F during the morning) elevates student exposure risk at bus stops and increases the chance of a district choosing a delay or cancellation, especially if they have a formal wind-chill threshold policy. The other meaningful safety trigger is the forecast’s repeated near-zero visibility signals (possible fog/low stratus/artifact); if real and coincident with 6–9 AM, it could tip the district toward closure. Net: modest but non-trivial snow-day probability, driven by cold + visibility/spot-ice uncertainty rather than snowfall.
keyFactors: No new precip expected Friday (0" snow / 0" precip), so the classic “impassable roads” trigger is unlikely; primary/treated roads should recover after Thursday operations.

Primary safety driver is *extreme cold exposure* during the AM bus-stop window: forecast wind chills roughly -20°F to -25°F from about 6–9 AM, matching the Cold Weather Advisory window and creating meaningful frostbite risk for uncovered skin during typical wait times.
Residual *spot-ice* risk from Thursday’s light freezing rain/snow + rapid refreeze: bridges/overpasses, shaded neighborhood streets, and parking lots could stay slick even with no new snowfall.

Visibility is the main “wildcard”: multiple hours show near-zero visibility (and freezing fog late evening). If that low vis shifts into the school commute window, it materially increases crash risk even without snow.

Operational vulnerabilities in arctic cold (bus no-starts, diesel gelling if not treated, door/air issues) can push districts toward a delay or selective cancellations; full closure is less common unless compounded by widespread travel hazard.

positions.rationale: From a news/operational-signals lens, the biggest ‘closure pressure’ I can justify is the *advisory-level extreme cold* plus evidence that districts locally have already closed this week under the broader storm/cold pattern. However, for **Friday, January 23, 2026**, the forecast itself is **dry (0 snow/0 precip)**, and the Winter Weather Advisory appears focused on Thursday rather than Friday. That usually means districts try to operate (often with a **2-hour delay** if anything) unless (a) wind chills meet a local hard threshold for multiple hours at pickup time, (b) lingering ice is widespread, or (c) an outage cluster emerges. With no confirmed outage spike and no official Rockford announcement in the captured sources, I’m keeping the probability in the low-to-moderate range, biased toward delay rather than a full closure.
keyFactors: **No new snow is forecast for Fri 2026-01-23** (0" precip/snow in the provided forecast). That usually keeps full closures relatively uncommon unless there’s ice/visibility/power issues.

**Cold Weather Advisory for Fri AM (wind chills ~-20°F to -25°F)** raises the odds of *delay* decisions (bus-stop exposure) and can sometimes tip districts toward closure if thresholds are strict or if conditions verify worse than forecast.

**Recent behavior/precedent:** multiple nearby districts (including Rockford-area districts) already closed midweek during this same pattern, signaling higher-than-normal willingness to cancel when travel/safety deteriorates.

**Residual travel risk from Thu’s wintry mix/advisory:** even with dry weather Friday, refreeze/black ice on bridges and neighborhood roads is plausible, which can combine with darkness (sunrise ~8:06 AM) to worsen the AM bus commute.

**Visibility flags are inconsistent but notable:** hourly forecast shows several “0 mi” visibility periods and freezing fog late night. If any of that shifts into the 6–9 AM window, cancellation odds rise.

However, for **Friday, January 23, 2026**, the forecast itself is **dry (0 snow/0 precip)**, and the Winter Weather Advisory appears focused on Thursday rather than Friday. That usually means districts try to operate (often with a **2-hour delay** if anything) unless (a) wind chills meet a local hard threshold for multiple hours at pickup time, (b) lingering ice is widespread, or (c) an outage cluster emerges. With no confirmed outage spike and no official Rockford announcement in the captured sources, I’m keeping the probability in the low-to-moderate range, biased toward delay rather than a full closure.

keyDisagreements.topic: Your pattern-based rates emphasize the ‘surprise hazard’ of freezing fog/near-zero visibility; meteorologically, the only explicit freezing-fog flag is late evening (23:00). If fog is not present 6–9 AM, I think the historical closure rate you’re leaning on may overstate the risk for *Friday* specifically.
positions: Your pattern-based rates emphasize the ‘surprise hazard’ of freezing fog/near-zero visibility; meteorologically, the only explicit freezing-fog flag is late evening (23:00). If fog is not present 6–9 AM, I think the historical closure rate you’re leaning on may overstate the risk for *Friday* specifically.

keyDisagreements.topic: Road risk is described as moderate, which I agree with, but the decision driver is more likely **wind chill policy** than roadway condition given 0 precip Friday. If you have any district-specific wind-chill threshold intel, that would materially shift the forecast.
positions: Road risk is described as moderate, which I agree with, but the decision driver is more likely **wind chill policy** than roadway condition given 0 precip Friday. If you have any district-specific wind-chill threshold intel, that would materially shift the forecast.

keyDisagreements.topic: The midweek closures signal is useful context, but it can overweight Friday’s decision because Thursday has active wintry precip/advisories while Friday is dry. I’d treat ‘already closed this week’ as a modest nudge, not a strong predictor, unless neighboring districts start announcing for Fri morning.
positions: The midweek closures signal is useful context, but it can overweight Friday’s decision because Thursday has active wintry precip/advisories while Friday is dry. I’d treat ‘already closed this week’ as a modest nudge, not a strong predictor, unless neighboring districts start announcing for Fri morning.

keyDisagreements.topic: Several hourly entries show 0-mile visibility at odd times with no precip; this may be a data/model artifact. If so, visibility/“freezing fog” should be down-weighted unless corroborated by another source or by the hourly narrative focusing on fog near dawn.
positions: Several hourly entries show 0-mile visibility at odd times with no precip; this may be a data/model artifact. If so, visibility/“freezing fog” should be down-weighted unless corroborated by another source or by the hourly narrative focusing on fog near dawn.

keyDisagreements.topic: The safety analysis leans toward ‘roads decent’ due to no new precip. Historically, arctic snaps after mixed precip can preserve/refreeze slush into hardpack/black ice on side roads, which can be worse than expected even when main roads are fine. I’d weight secondary-road risk slightly higher than primary-road conditions imply.
positions: The safety analysis leans toward ‘roads decent’ due to no new precip. Historically, arctic snaps after mixed precip can preserve/refreeze slush into hardpack/black ice on side roads, which can be worse than expected even when main roads are fine. I’d weight secondary-road risk slightly higher than primary-road conditions imply.

collaboration.collaborationSummary: Agents reached consensus after 1 round(s) with 6.0% spread. Average probability: 24%.

alert.headline: Winter Weather Advisory issued January 21 at 9:22PM EST until January 22 at 7:00PM EST by NWS Grand Rapids MI
alert.areas: Mason; Lake; Oceana; Newaygo; Muskegon; Ottawa; Kent; Allegan; Barry; Van Buren; Kalamazoo
alert.desc:
* WHAT...Snow. Additional snow accumulations tonight between 2 and 5
inches, and an additional 1 to 3 on Thursday. Winds gusting as
high as 35 mph.

* WHERE...Portions of southwest and west central Michigan.

* WHEN...Until 7 PM EST Thursday.

* IMPACTS...Roads, and especially bridges and overpasses, will
likely become slick and hazardous. Visibility and road conditions
may change rapidly over short distances in lake effect snow. Plan
on slippery road conditions. The hazardous conditions could impact
the Thursday morning and evening commutes.
alert.instruction:
Slow down and use caution while traveling.

During lake effect snow, the weather can vary from bands of locally
heavy snow to dry weather just a few miles away. Visibilities can
also vary greatly. Be prepared for rapid changes in weather,
visibility, and road conditions.

alert.headline: Extreme Cold Watch issued January 21 at 9:22PM EST until January 24 at 10:00AM EST by NWS Grand Rapids MI
alert.areas: Mason; Lake; Osceola; Clare; Oceana; Newaygo; Mecosta; Isabella; Muskegon; Montcalm; Gratiot; Ottawa; Kent; Ionia; Clinton; Allegan; Barry; Eaton; Ingham; Van Buren; Kalamazoo; Calhoun; Jackson
alert.desc:
* WHAT...Dangerously cold wind chills as low as 25 below possible.

* WHERE...Portions of central, south central, southwest, and west
central Michigan.

* WHEN...From late Thursday night through Saturday morning.

* IMPACTS...The dangerously cold wind chills as low as 25 below zero
could cause frostbite on exposed skin in as little as 30 minutes.
Frostbite and hypothermia will occur if unprotected skin is
exposed to these temperatures. An extended period of freezing
temperatures could cause ruptured water pipes.
alert.instruction:
Monitor the latest forecasts and warnings for updates.

Avoid outside activities if possible. When outside, make sure you
wear appropriate clothing, a hat, and gloves.

Make frequent checks on older family, friends, and neighbors. Ensure
portable heaters are used correctly. Do not use generators or grills
inside.

alert.headline: Cold Weather Advisory issued January 22 at 2:43AM EST until January 24 at 10:00AM EST by NWS Grand Rapids MI
alert.areas: Mason; Lake; Osceola; Clare; Oceana; Newaygo; Mecosta; Isabella; Muskegon; Montcalm; Gratiot; Ottawa; Kent; Ionia; Clinton; Allegan; Barry; Eaton; Ingham; Van Buren; Kalamazoo; Calhoun; Jackson
alert.desc:
* WHAT...Very cold wind chills as low as 20 to 25 below expected
Friday morning. Continued significant cold Friday and Friday night.

* WHERE...Portions of central, south central, southwest, and west
central Michigan.

* WHEN...From 1 AM Friday to 10 AM EST Saturday.

* IMPACTS...The dangerously cold wind chills approaching 25 below
zero could cause frostbite on exposed skin in as little as 30
minutes. Frostbite and hypothermia will occur if unprotected skin
is exposed to these temperatures.
alert.instruction:
Use caution while outdoors. Wear appropriate clothing, a hat, and
gloves. Keep pets indoors as much as possible and consider making
checks on older family, friends, and neighbors. Ensure portable
heaters are used correctly. Do not use generators or grills inside.
